title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from Afghanistan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Afghanistan?
preds: Actually, the distribution of causalties in wars and terrorism follows a power-law distribution. The larger single killing per-year in Afghanistan is around 100 civilians, some years larger, some years smaller, but that indicates that the probability of a 1000 civilian killing is (100/1000)^2.5, or about 0.3%, maybe a bit larger if the exponent happens to be smaller. I round it to 1%, which is still a bit too pesimistic.

I'm not sure I'm getting the "mass killing" definition right which might make this tricky. On the website of EWP they state that the Taliban already engages in a "mass killing episode" against "non-combatant civilians suspected of supporting Afghan government or NATO Coalition Forces" since 2001 [1]. In their own risk assessment of Afghanistan, they state that this only "relates to the possibility of a new and distinct non-state-led or state-led episode beginning, not to the likelihood of Taliban attacks continuing or increasing." [2] From the phrasing here on GJP it's not clear at all whether this only refers to such new episode and not the Taliban one. However, I will assume that it does indeed refer to new episodes, and not a continuation of the Taliban one. Base rate: not clear at all how one would calculate this here. EWP only has "ongoing mass killings", but not a list of all recorded ones as far as I could find. Eye-balling this gives about 0-3 new such mass killings per year. Let's assume 1 on average for now. Let's say there are about 30 to 50 countries which are reasonably at risk of such an episode (including Afghanistan). That gives 2-3% as a base rate. This fits kind of well with the global average of 2.6% that EWP gives. (I'm somewhat surprised by this high number though as a **global** average.) A wider distribution would give a reasonable interval between 1% (1 out of 100) to 10% (3 out of 30). This seems about right. Other judgments:
- EWP itself gives a probability of 24.1% [3]
- CFR lists Afghanistan as a "Top Conflict to Watch in 2019" [4]
- crowd forecast here is 2% Insight view:
- If we assume that the Taliban do not count, other plausible perpetrators are: (1) military forces of Afghanistan, (2) Islamic State, (3) other
- (1) seems extremely unlikely. While governance is bad, I think there is only an extremely low chance that the government would **deliberately** target civilians,  <1%.
- (2) seems plausible: In 2018, "UNAMA attributed 2,181 civilian casualties (681 deaths and 1,500 injured) to Daesh/ISKP, an increase of 118 per cent compared to 2017, comprising 20 per cent of all civilian casualties." [5] If this trend holds, this would constitute another instance of mass killing resolving the question positively. In fact, the increase would only need to be ~50%, not 118%. However, violence seems to have decreased over the previous months. They also seem to have suffered some setbacks last year. They are still operational though with about 2,000 fighters [6], and continue to target civilians. [7][8] They are not part of the peace talks as far as I can tell. 
- (3) seems less likely. It's unclear which actors this would be. While "UNAMA attributed 678 civilian casualties (196 deaths and 482 injured) to undetermined Anti-Government Elements" [5], this does not constitute a campaign. I estimate about 1%, maybe 2% at worst.  Overall judgment:
- The crowd forecast of 2% seems far too low, both given the base rate, EWP judgment, and insight view.
- I'm not sure how to reason well about this to be honest. There are between 20,000 to 40,000 Taliban fighters [9], compared to only 2,000 Daesh fighters. Naively, they should never be able to reach the Taliban numbers in terms of civilian deaths, but they were already at about 50% last year, far beyond the expected 5-10%. So this doesn't tell us much.
